data.name: Shorthand large and small numbers
data.description:
`shorthand(n)` Gets number `n` and returns the shorthand (Scientific notation) version of it. For this number: 50,000,000 the shorthand will be this: 5\*107 To make your life easier, you don't need to worry about superscript and instead return this string: `5*10^7` ## Some examples: ```javascript shorthand(5000000) //returns 5*10^6 shorthand(532000) //returns 5.32*10^5 shorthand(-2000) //returns -2*10^3 shorthand(0.00005) //returns 5*10^-5 ``` ## Some specifics: *
Any given integer can be written in the form m×10n in many ways: for example, 350 can be written as 3.5×102 or 35×101 or 350×100. In normalized scientific notation, the exponent n is chosen so that the absolute value of m remains at least one but less than ten (1 ≤ |m| < 10). Thus 350 is written as 3.5×102
* `shorthand(1000)` should return `10^3` **NOT** `1*10^3` since the `1` is redundant. * `shorthand(1.5333)` already has coefficient `m` 1 ≤ |m| < 10; return number as is (up to 3 decimal places): `1.533` All numbers are to be rounded to 3 decimal places (1.001) and no more. Consult this when in doubt: [Scientific Notation#Normalized_notation](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_notation#Normalized_notation) NOTE: All the numbers tested will be within the safe max/min size. (No really really big/small numbers) Smallest number you'll handle is: 0.000001 (10^-6), highest number is: 999900000000000000000 (9.999*10^20)

Note: Number.toExponential() is disabled
